detaileddescription.para: Base address for the DMA control table, must be 1024 bytes aligned
Make sure DMA control table base address is 1024 bytes aligned
Compiler specific macros to allocate DMA control table entries
Sets the DMA transfer size in number of items
Gets the DMA transfer size in number of items

briefdescription.para: A handle that is returned from a UDMACC26XX_open() call.
Function to initialize the CC26XX DMA driver.

detaileddescription.para: The function will set the isOpen flag to false, and should be called prior to opening the DMA driver.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize the CC26XX DMA peripheral.

detaileddescription.para: The function will set a dependency on the peripheral power domain, i.e. power up the module and enable the clock. Note this function always uses the first DMA entry in the global UDMACC26XX_config list.

simplesect.para: UDMACC26XX_init() has to be called first. Calling context: Task
UDMACC26XX_Handle on success or NULL if error or if it has been already opened

briefdescription.para: Function to close the DMA driver.

detaileddescription.para: Will disable the DMA hardware, release the power dependency and destruct the HWI interrupt.

simplesect.para: UDMACC26XX_open() has to be called first. Calling context: Task

detaileddescription.para: The UDMACC26XX header file should be included in an application as follows: #include<ti/drivers/dma/UDMACC26XX.h>

The UDMACC26XX driver currently only supports internal use by the drivers that use the uDMA peripheral (e.g., SPICC26X2DMA). In other words, the application should never call any of the functions in this file.

This driver is used implicitly by other drivers (e.g., the SPICC26X2DMA driver) so users should not have to interface to this driver from the application. The uDMA HW makes use of a control table in RAM which must be 1024 bytes aligned. The default base address of this control table is 0x20000400, however this can be changed by simply changing UDMACC26XX_CONFIG_BASE. The SPICC26X2DMA.h supports SPI0 and SPI1, and uses both TX and RX DMA channels. Each control table entry is 16 bytes, so if an application uses both SSI0 and SSI1 the total RAM usage will be 4*16=64 bytes. If only one SSI module is used only 2*16=32 bytes of RAM is used. Please see Use cases for example.
Error handling is handled by the overlying driver which uses the DMA.
Power management is handled by the overlying driver which uses the DMA.
Note that these functions should never be called from the application, they are only called from other drivers. They are however included here for completeness:

entry.para: Initialize and enable the uDMA HW and set system dependencies.
Disable uUDMA HW and release system dependencies

simplesect.para: These functions should not be called by code. These functions are called by drivers who're using the DMA.

detaileddescription.para: The DMA peripheral is unable to access flash memory in the address range 0x0000 - 0x2000 on devices based on the Cortex M33+ core (CC26X3/CC26X4) due to security constraints.

The DMA is only used internally by other drivers, so the application should never call any of the functions in this driver directly. The only thing that the application is allowed to modify is the base address of the DMA control table in RAM. (Default value is 0x2000_0400) Remember it must be 1024 bytes aligned. #defineUDMACC26XX_CONFIG_BASE0x2000_0400

listitem.para: If only SSI0 is used, this will allocate 2*16=32 RAM bytes at address: [0x2000_0430-0x2000_044F] = SSI0 RX/TX DMA channels
If only SSI1 is used, this will allocate 2*16=32 RAM bytes at address: [0x2000_0500-0x2000_051F] = SSI1 RX/TX DMA channels
If both SSI0 and SSI1 are used, this will allocate 4*16=64 RAM bytes at addresses: [0x2000_0430-0x2000_044F] = SSI0 RX/TX DMA channels [0x2000_0500-0x2000_051F] = SSI1 RX/TX DMA channels
